title: msp-riverside-medical-practice-cannot-expand-boundary-issues-fixed
story: Colin Beattie MSP said this decision followed talks with Jeane Freeman MSP, Cabinet Secretary for Health and Sport.Last year, the Primary Care Contractor Organisation outlined plans to alter the practice boundary to take patients from the Blindwells new town development.Construction is set to get under way on the first of the , phase one homes at the former opencast mine site between Prestonpans and Longniddry.Over the next decade and beyond, up to , new homes and community facilities are expected to be built there.Also proposed is a ldquoLevenhall Queen Margaret University extension as part of the boundary change at the Riverside GP practice.The practice is based at Musselburgh Primary Care Centre , along with Inveresk Medical Practice, which is separate.After it merged with Eskbridge Medical Practice, Riverside became the largest practice in East Lothian and one of the biggest in Scotland, with about , patients.Mr Beattie said: ldquoFrom correspondence with local constituents, it was clear to me that action needed to be taken to remedy the ongoing issues in relation to Riverside Medical Practice.ldquoI have spoken with Jeane Freeman, the Cabinet Secretary for Health and Sport, who is now working closely with NHS Lothian to ensure that a solution is found.ldquoIt was decided that the best route forward was to allow no further boundary expansions of the practice until the service is ing at a satisfactory standard.ldquoI am sure that this decision will be welcomed by all those who have concerns about the practice.He added: ldquoOf course, the NHS does not have complete control over the operations of the practice, given that the doctors are simply contracted by the NHS to run this service. However, NHS Lothian will work closely with the management going forward to ensure their budget is managed more effectively, and that the issues at hand are adequately addressed.Members of Musselburgh and Inveresk Community Council have also told health bosses that the proposed boundary expansion would be ldquoa step in the wrong direction.The group contacted the Primary Care Contractor Organisation, stressing that it was ldquoabsolutely opposed to any change in the boundary area.Members also called for a meeting with health bosses, which took place recently at the practice and involved: Irene Tait, community council chairperson Margaret Stewart, community council secretary Holly Kilday, a community council member Dr Richard Fairclough and Dr Joana Stenke of Riverside Medical Practice ward councillors Stuart Currie and Katie Mackie Iain Gorman, East Lothian Health and Social Care Partnershiprsquos head of operations and Councillor Fiona OrsquoDonnell, chairperson of East Lothian Integration Joint Board.The community councillors highlighted complaints they had received from members of the community, including:A statement issued by the community council following the discussion said: ldquoWe wondered why on earth the practice would want to take on more of a workload when clearly they are not coping with what they have to deal with at present.ldquoThe practice acknowledged the fact that they had undergone many changes in the last few years, not least the fact that they are on their third telephone system.ldquoThe practice also stated they will need to step up to the mark with a communication plan, making sure that everyone in our community is aware of how the practice is working and what options are available to them.ldquoThe expectation from the public is,they phone for a doctorsrsquo appointment, they will see a doctor and this is not always going to be the case.ldquoWhen you call you will be given two options, same day or non-urgent, and this will enable the staff to put you on to the right person who can help and this could be NHS , paramedics, physio, mental health or occupational therapistor alternatively, a doctornecessary on the same day.Wrong direction ldquoWe discussed the boundaries and made them aware that we felt that to take on Blindwells would be a step in the wrong direction.ldquoThe meeting was quite positive and hopefully, moving forward, we will keep in touch with the practice and they with us so that everyone is kept informed.Dr Stenke and Dr Fairclough issued a joint statement, saying: ldquoWe were delighted to meet with the Musselburgh and Inveresk Community Council representatives and local councillors. We felt it was a really positive opportunity to discuss many of the changes that have happened in Musselburgh over the last few years to stabilise and develop primary care services.ldquoIt is really important for us at Riverside to understand the views of the community we serve, which can be hugely supportive in improving services. For example, feedback on our old phone system helped us to understand the issues that our patients were experiencing and led to us developing a new telephone system that was more suitable for our patientsrsquo needs as well as those of the practice.ldquoRiverside, along with other practices in the county, are collaborating with and supporting East Lothianrsquos Health and Social Care Partnershiprsquos plan to grow health services to meet the needs of a growing population.ldquoWe remain keen to improve our engagement and communication with the local community, and the meeting was a positive step to build links with local groups.ldquoWe are grateful to the community council representatives and local councillors for taking the time to visit us at Riverside Medical Practice and we look forward to developing a closer and collaborative relationship with them.An East Lothian Health and Social Care Partnership spokesperson said: ldquoWe thought the meeting with Riverside and the community council was very positive. We were impressed by Riversidersquos commitment to engaging with the community and communicating developments. We look forward to supporting them in any way that we can.Councillor Mackie added: ldquoIt was a helpful meeting with community stakeholders and local GPs. title: claim-buildings-haddington-street-left-shaking-large-vehicles
story: Concerns about the speed of vehicles and the condition of the buildings on the historic street were raised at Haddingtonrsquos community council meeting.Members heard from David Barrett, who lives near the busy town centre street and felt that something needed to be done.However, he claimed he had raised the issue with East Lothian Council previously ndash only to allegedly be told that nothing could be done until the buildings started falling onto the street.Mr Barrett said: ldquoI think one of the paradoxes about Market Street is we all see it during the day and Friday afternoon, it is more like Oxford Circus. You can walk faster than the traffic.ldquoBut between am and am, and between pm and am, huge agricultural vehicles and HGVs actually hit  miles plus per hour through the town and our buildings shake, they physically shake.Mr Barrett was keen to see something done to slow vehicles down on the busy street.He said: ldquoIrsquom suggesting that some type of traffic calming is very necessary to preserve the fabric of the historic buildings.However, the idea of large vehicles doing more than  miles per hour on Market Street was refuted by Rab Moran.The community councillor, who was an HGV driver for about  years, said: ldquoI used to be an HGV driver and there is no way an articulated lorry or anything  for that matter clatters along Market Street at  miles per hour.ldquoYou sometimes donrsquot get up to  miles per hour going along there.Mr Moran stressed that it was a rural community and there were occasions where farm machinery needed to use the roads.Fellow community councillor Chris McEwan said there were issues with putting in traffic calming measures, such as speed humps.He said: ldquoSpeed humps are going to be absolutely useless to anything over a normal car size.ldquoThey are designed so ambulances can carry over.ldquoThey would not slow down trucks or anything .A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council confirmed that the issue was being investigated.She said: ldquoWe are aware of Mr Barrettrsquos concerns and have advised that the council is currently looking at measures concerning traffic movement in and around Haddington.ldquoThese plans may include consideration of traffic calming options to reduce speeds in certain areas.

title: met-office-name-storms-names-ruled
story: After a mild start to the year, we have been battered by heavy rain and severe gales.But who comes up with the names for storms and whats next Why do the Met Office name storms The Met Office first decided to givestorms a namein  with the first one named Abigail in November .The hope was that naming severe storms wouldmake people more aware of them and how dangerous they can be.And it makes iteasier to follow the progress of a storm on the TV, radio, or on social media,it has a name.Can I suggest a storm name Every summer the Met Office andMet Eacuteireann askpeople to send in their ideas for future storm names.Look out for their #NameOurStorms campaign on social media around July this year for the chance for your name to be included.A new list of names will be compiled jointly between Met Eacuteireann,the Met Office and KNMIin September for the following   storm season.What are the storm names for this year Weve already had:Dennis is set to arrive this weekend and then weve got:Names alternate between male and female and run from A-Z based on some of the more popular names suggested to the Met Office as well as reflecting the ersity of Britain, Ireland and the Netherlands.To ensure the Met Office is in line with the US National Hurricane Centre naming conventions, names which begin with the letters Q, U, X, Y and Z are not included.Are there any names the Met Office has ruled out Among the names suggested to the Met Office, officials have rejected anything that isnt a proper name.That includes:Apocalypse, Baldrick, Big Boss, Gnasher, Hot Brew, root ripper, Stormageddon, Ssswetcaroline, Vader, Voldermort and branch wobbler.Other rejected names included Hammer, Hades,Forkbeard, Megatron andIn A Teacup.

title: waterside-bistro-chief-takes-castle-inn-dirleton
story: Brothers Jack and James Findlay have been at the helm of the Waterside Bistro, next to the River Tyne in Haddington, for more than two-and-a-half years.The eaterie was founded by their dad Jim, who also previously ran The Drovers Inn in East Linton, and The Rocks on Dunbarrsquos Marine Road.Now, Jack is expanding the empire by taking over The Castle Inn.He told the Courier: ldquoWe have had quite a soft opening, we just opened yesterday [last Wednesday].ldquoI think the area is lovely and my dad was born in Dirleton, so there is a little bit of heritage there.ldquoWe will be basing it a lot on the Waterside model and obviously myself and my brother will be working alongside each other but from afar.ldquoWe have had tremendous success at the Waterside and we both felt it was probably the right time to look where.ldquoThe Castle Inn was the perfect fit for us.ldquoIt will be myself here and my brother is still based in Haddington.ldquoMy dad is lsquoretiredrsquo but will just be popping in and making sure we are going in the right direction.Twenty-eight-year-old Jack said they already had a good team in place and there were no plans for any ldquodrastic changes.A focus would be placed on locally sourced food, with a daily list of specials.He added: ldquoI would also like to mention the former owners John Dawson and Bert DrsquoAgostino, and want to pay a bit of a tribute to them for their fine work in the trade.ldquoJohn has been fantastic with me and very helpful.

title: Iain Macwhirter  The reunification of Ireland is surely just a matter of time
story: Ha ha, say nationalists. The way things are going itrsquoll likely be a bridge between two independent countries.There is Sinn Fein winning the popular vote in Ireland and demanding a referendum on reunication. And Scotland is to have one next year, according to Nicola Sturgeon.Well, in your dreams.Therersquos unlikely to be a Scottish referendum any time soon. Sinn Fein is in no position to demand a border poll, while it remains a minority in the Irish parliament, the Dail.It wasnrsquot only or even mainly Sinn Feinrsquos policy on a United Ireland that drove leader May Lou McDonaldrsquos success. The campaign focused on housing, health and pensions.Moreover, not everyone in the Republic is enthusiastic about reuniting with the North. Even some nationalists worry about taking responsibility for the pound billion or so the UK pumps annually into The Six Counties, as Sinn Feincalls the province.Then therersquos all the sectarianism and the legacy of the Troubles. Unionist paramilitaries havenrsquot gone away either. This makes it all the more remarkable that what used to be the political wing of the Irish Republican Army has become a major player in Irish politics. SF was regarded as de facto terrorist itself until recently. The idea it could ever get near forming a governing coalition was regarded as ridiculous.But after this election, Sinn Fein can no longer be dismissed as a relic of sectarianism. It came top with  per cent of the popular vote against  per cent for Fianna Dail and  per cent for Leo Varadkarrsquos Fine Gael. Had Mary Lou McDonald fielded more candidates, SF might have won more than its  seats in the Dail, one fewer than Fianna Faacuteil. It was a rare case of a political party actually under-estimating its electoral support.Seismic is an overused term in politics,but this election really is earthshaking, not least for the future of the UK. Leo Varadkar, the Fine Gael Taoiseach, has been looking suitably shaken.He insists he will not contemplate any alliance with ldquoextremist Sinn Feiners, one of whose TDs launched into a rendition of the Irish rebel song ldquoCome out ye Black and Tans at a Dublin count. Michael Martin of Fianna Faacuteil isnrsquot ruling out a coalition but is instinctively hostile.The establishment parties will do all in their power to lock Sinn Fein out of office during the coming weeks of coalition horse trading. But it seems unlikely they can keep the charismatic Mary Lou in her box.This is because nationalism is back in a big way in Ireland as in the UK. Yes, the grievances of young people without housing and older folk worried about pensions arenrsquot intrinsically nationalist. But these grievances are now being expressed by voting for the party of Irish nationalism par excellence.It is similar to the way many Scottish voters, with similar complaints, turned suddenly to the independence cause in , obliterating Labour in Scotland.Radical nationalism is now the driving force in modern politics. It is redrawing the political map across Europe as voters turn away from neoliberalism and globalism.We see it in the Yellow Vest movement in France, in populist parties in Italy and, yes, even in Brexit. That was essentially an English nationalist rebellion against the EU.The BBCrsquos former World Affairs Editor, John Simpson, attracted much criticism for tweeting his regret that Ireland had ldquosuccumbed to populism. The implication is that Sinn Fein remain extremist and its success is a bad thing.Commentators like Simpson used to say much the same about Alex Salmondrsquos SNP. Many metropolitan intellectuals still regard populism as synonymous with racism and bigotry.But this equation of nationalist movements with the political right makes little sense. Both the SNP and Sinn Fein triumphed from the left. All nationalisms not the same.Fianna Faacuteil and Fine Gael are also nominally nationalist parties, dating from the Irish Civil War. Theyrsquore ldquoSoldiers of Destiny and ldquoTribe of the Irish respectively. Sinn Fein, meaning ldquoWe Ourselves actually sounds less militantly nationalist.In recent years theyrsquove become identikit centrist parties. Fine Gael is generally considered slightly more right wing and pro big business than Fianna Faacuteil, which used to represent farmers and small business. But itrsquos hard to tell. The two old parties are basically rival networks of patronage, cronyism even, with little ideological depth.Fianna Faacuteil had the misfortune to be in office during the  financial crash, which hit Ireland hard. The country was traumatised by the weight of debt left by the collapse of the Irish banks.Fine Gael under its seemingly more progressive Taoiseach, Leo Varadkar, thought it had inherited the upswing. In GDP terms it has. Ireland has one of the highest growth rates in Europe and national income per head is higher than the UKrsquos.Mr Varadkar, who is openly gay, won plaudits for legalising abortion and same-sex marriage. But this progressive gloss did not prevent Fine Gael being seen as in the pockets of rampant capitalism.He won the battle of Brexit too, but lost the war for domestic popularity as young and old turned in disgust from the grotesque inequalities of wealth in Ireland. Brexit was not, by common consent, a signicant issue in the election. But it must have played a part,only subliminally.The North is to remain in regulatory alignment with the Republic, while Britain erects a border in the Irish Sea. This de facto economic reunication of Ireland has transformed the border question.Itrsquos no longer a question of Brits out. Theyrsquore going. Irish nationalism is no longer about the gun, but about the EU single market. The dream of Irish unity is becoming a reality through the ballot box. Formal unication seems only a matter of time.The SNP has historically shunned Sinn Fein, fearing guilt by association. That must surely now change. It is now a legitimate democratic force.But there is a warning here for Nicola Sturgeon. The SNP canrsquot afford to abandon its left-wing radicalism, or trade it for LGBT and gender politics. If the SNP becomes another party of the establishment it could share the fate of Leo Varadkar.

title: transport-secretary-brands-idea-northern-ireland-bridge-link-vanity-project
story: Boris Johnson has said work is under way to establish the feasibility of a road crossing between Portpatrick in Dumfries and Galloway and Larne in Co Antrim.The devolved administrations said the estimated pound billion cost should fund vital projects in both countries instead and expressed anger that they had not been consulted.:Whitehall officials begin scoping work on Boris Bridge linking Scotland and Northern IrelandScottish transport secretary Michael Matheson said: ldquoI strongly believe thatpound billion is available for investment in infrastructure in Scotland and Northern Ireland that, rather than indulging the Prime Minister with this vanity project, such funding should be made available to our respective governments so it could be better spent on meeting the priorities of the people we represent.Downing Street said a ldquorange of officials were looking at the idea, but was unable to say how many civil servants were examining proposals.The Prime Ministerrsquos official spokesman said it was a ldquoproper piece of work and Mr Johnson was ldquoambitious about infrastructure projects across the country.Mr Johnson has repeatedly spoken about the prospect of a bridge, even though experts have warned that the depth of the Irish Sea and the presence of dumped munitions would cause problems for any project.Stormont infrastructure minister Nichola Mallon said: ldquoI am extremely concerned that pursuit of this project, costing pound billion, will be a waste of signicant money and resource that could be put to better use by addressing pressures and deliverable projects here in Northern Ireland and where.ldquoBy spending just a fraction of the reported cost of this bridge, I am of the view that we could bring signicantly more benefits to people across the north by investing in infrastructure here and making a real dference to improving the lives of citizens across Northern Ireland.The distance from Larne to Portpatrick, one of the most likely routes for a bridge, is around  miles.There is no problem with distance, money or the Beaufortrsquos Dyke explosives disposal area, according to the Prime Minister.:Prime Minister brands idea of Boris bridge between Scotland and Northern Ireland very interestingAn engineer has suggested the span could be ready within  years.In a letter to UK Transport Secretary Grant Shapps, Mr Matheson called for urgent talks with the UK Government.He wrote: ldquoGiven transport is devolved to both the Scottish Government and Northern Ireland Executive, I look forward to hearing from you on the availability of the pound billion to us, and to assurances that in future any such proposals will be discussed with us first and will fully respect the devolved settlements and the role of the Northern Ireland Assembly and the Scottish Parliament.

title: unspun-political-diary
story: A REDDER face than usual this week for Jackson Carlaw after he slagged the Queensferry Crossing for closing due to falling ice. It later turned out the Scottish Tory boss led the obscure Holyrood committee that chose the ldquostunning design and approved the route. So who dobbed him in  Jackson may like to thank his predecessor, Ruth Davidson, who on the day of the closure was doing The Stooshie podcast and chirpily volunteered: ldquoIt was Jackson Carlaw who was head of the steering group on the bridge, as I recall.Chest intentionsSTILL, Mr Jackson had a better day on Friday, when he trounced rival Michelle Ballantyne in his partyrsquos leadership race. Mr Carlaw won by three-to-one in a result dubbed the Ballantynersquos Day Massacre. Mr Carlaw is desperate to shed his image as a th hole Tory throwback and look to the future. Very odd then to see his deputy Liam Kerr in an open-necked black shirt with a quf of chest hair showing. All that was needed for the full retro disco look was a gold medallion and a splash of Old Spice.Comfort foodTEAM Ballantyne put on a brave face. lsquoI think itrsquoll be - to Jackson,rsquo said one naive soul just before the result was declared. Ms Ballantynersquos husband Neil, who knew the truth, was more grounded as he scampered around among the troops. ldquoWersquoll go for lunch afterwards, thatrsquos the main thing, he told them. In search of crumbs of comfort, no doubt.Yer tearsquos ootMUCH grumbling among Holyrood underlings at Holyrood magazinersquos bid to drum up nominations for its annual awards. The magrsquos editor has urged MSPs to put their aides forward for Staffer of the Year as the category ldquois the vitally important one that is going to ensure you get a cup of coffee when you want one. Who knows  You might even get your biscuit dunked. lsquoItrsquos mortying,rsquo huffs our mole. lsquoItrsquos like we came into politics to make the tea.rsquo Oops.Taking the pizzaHOLYROODrsquoS chefs love to experiment on their customers - sorry, with food. The primordial gloop of their banana and chocolate crumble is testimony to that. This week saw even wilder gastronomic daredevilry with the lsquoNutella calzone pizzarsquo. As daunting mentally as physically, the vast hazelnut-choc bridies seemed to have few takers on Tuesday. With Storm Ciara threatening to snow people in, one wag observed: ldquoI bet theyrsquore still untouched when the cannibalism starts.Been there Don thatSO farewell then, finally, to Richard Lyle. One of Unspunrsquos regulars, the Lanarkshire leg-breaker has told colleagues hersquos standing down at the  election. Mr Lyle, famed as lsquoSalty Dickrsquo at Holyrood for once claiming a bag of chips on his expenses, was part of an SNP faction dubbed the Monklands McMafia. Now his Uddingston  Bellshill candidacy is up for grabs, a Nat turf war looms over who gets it. There will be tears. Some salty, perhaps. But most, Unspun hears from local activists, of pure joy.

title: new-rules-introduced-combat-price-hikes-phone-internet-deals
story: Ofcom says around  million customers are already out of contract, including . million paying for broadband.In some cases Which  found bills nearly doubled when the promotional period elapsed and reverted to standard fees.The problem was exacerbated it said because nearly half of customers remain with the same provider for three years or more instead of shopping around or haggling for a better deal.: Hip and knee ops cancelled in Ayrshire after surgeons arrestUntil now, providers were not required to remind their customers when their contract is about to end or warn that bills may go up.The new measures enforced by Ofcom will mean that home telecom firms must inform their customers between  and  days before their contract expires, via a text message, email or letter.The rules apply to mobile phone contracts, internet and satellite or cable television.The notication must also state any notice period for leaving their provider, the best deals available, and reveal any prices only available to new customers.Anyone already out of contract must be sent a reminder every year of the best options on offer.Ofcom says the average broadband customer could save around pound a year following the change, though some could save pound or more.The regulator also estimates that around three million people could upgrade to a faster broadband package and still pay less.Lindsey Fussell, Ofcoms consumer group director, said: "Millions of people are out of contract right now and paying more than they need to."These new rules make it easier to grab a better deal. But you dont need to wait to hear from your provider.": Flagship plan for superfast broadband could be delivered three years latePrevious research by Which  found that broadband customers who switch or haggle with their current provider for a better deal were able to cut an average of pound a year from their bills.The next biggest hike was TalkTalk, where the cost of a phone and broadband package went from pound. to pound a month after two years, followed by Virgin Media where bills shot up from pound to pound at the end of a -month contract.: Ofcom criticises BBC over failure to attract young audiencesWhich  said Ofcom must monitor and review the progress of the new regulations to ensure it is effective for consumers.Natalie Hitchins, Which  head of home products and services, said: ldquoOur research shows that far too many people are paying more than they need to for broadband, so this rule change to ensure people are notied before their contract ends - and potentially before their bills go up - is a positive step."Andrew Glover, chair of the Internet Service Providers Association , which includes operators such as BT, Sky and Virgin, said the changes should be allowed to "bed in fully" before any further regulation is considered.He added: "Industry is supportive of end of contract notications as an additional way to help consumers make an informed choice about their broadband."

title: tom-gordon-carlaw-chameleon-can-change-look-not-reality
story: But Jackson Carlaw did just that after being elected Scottish Conservative leader yesterday.Casting around for a bad lot to set beside Nicola Sturgeonrsquos SNP, Mr Carlaw chose John Majorrsquos wretched government of  to  as the epitome of dys.ldquoThis is a failing government on its last legs, he said of the SNP. ldquoItrsquos morally and politically bankrupt. Itrsquos got nothing new to say, nothing new to offer.ldquoI remember the Major government in  winning an election in the spring and then being behind in the polls and out of office after that. The SNP are in much the same position as we go into next yearrsquos election.ldquoThey are there to be replaced... an exhausted government which is failing on every single domestic front.ldquoI think for a long time people overlooked that, but actually I think now they want an alternative. You canrsquot have a one party state. They need to believe therersquos something better and itrsquos now incumbent upon us to be the party that offers that.It was a sign Mr Carlaw is not like other Scottish Tory leaders."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Carlaw elected as Scottish Conservatives leader","description": "Carlaw elected as Scottish Conservatives leader","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media rIOddQP poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests rIOddQP.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": He thinks he has a catrsquos chance of power, for one thing. Re-election as a strong opposition no longer cuts it.He has set himself a hard target.He wants the Scottish Tories to be the largest party at Holyrood next year. If he fails, as he failed to keep most of his MPs at the general election, itrsquos all over for the Eastwood MSP.:Jackson Carlaw elected new leader of Scottish ConservativesIf the SNP win a majority, it also could be all over for the Union, Boris Johnson and the Tories at Westminster too. So Mr Carlaw is gearing up to go hell for leather into .On the basis of recent comments, shamelessness is a key part of the plan.Unpopular policies are to be binned in a sweeping review. Past support for university tuition fees and the two-child benefit cap that gave us the lsquorape clausersquo look ripe for the chop.Mr Carlaw says he wants the best policies for Scotland in the s, not out-dated post-Crash austerity.Expect a starring role for theft, too.Large chunks of Mr Carlawrsquos speech and media briefing yesterday could have easily appeared in SNP, Labour or Liberal Democrat manestos.The word ldquofairness kept cropping up. Fairness in education, fairness in healthcare, fairness at work, fairness in housing. ldquoI will lead a party... for which fairness for all is a guiding principle, announced the former Glasgow Academy pupil.No shrinking violet when it comes to blocking another independence referendum, Mr Carlaw also said he wanted to ldquoput the constitutional arguments behind us and focus on what voters want. The Carlaw chameleon is a very adaptable beast.With Scottish Labour a busted flush and the LibDems in the post-Brexit doldrums, Mr Carlaw evidently hopes his party can occupy swathes of the centre ground in , a generic, unthreatening everyman party that can appeal to voters who would previously have gone where.If Boris Johnson can demolish a red wall, maybe Mr Carlaw slice through the central belt. Well, in theory.The reality does not look good.The Tories won  MSPs in , less than half the SNPrsquos . Thatrsquos still more than the base Alex Salmond had going into the  election, when he increased his tally from  to .But Labour only had  MSPs in , and it only fell to . The SNP barely scratched the main party of government. It won by picking up MSPs on regional lists, largely at the expense of the Greens and Socialists.However  of todayrsquos  Tory MSPs are on the lists. Theyrsquore unlikely to improve much on that.The Tories need to take seats from the SNP and ramp up their vote share on the list to make serious progress.That is a very tall order.Mr Carlaw says he wants to overhaul the list system to get more women and ethnic minority candidates in winnable positions.Culling the current deadwood wonrsquot hurt, but it wonrsquot do much to the overall numbers. Meddling with the list system is also going to put Mr Carlaw in conflict with the party membership, who covet their ability to determine the list rankings.He doesnrsquot have time for a fight.But the most important number to emerge yesterday was not Mr Jacksonrsquos % win, it was the partyrsquos membership. This is usually secret.:Next Scottish Conservative leader warned not to lsquokowtowrsquo to Boris JohnsonThe last time it surfaced was during the  leadership election, when it was just under ,. Almost a decade on, it is now just under ,.The SNPrsquos is ten times that.True, Mr Johnson can steer Tory donor cash Mr Carlawrsquos way in , but the Tory ground operation is pitul compared to the SNPrsquos army.Mr Carlawrsquos comparison with the Major government is also wishful thinking. The Major government was dysal on a truly epic scale.It was crippled within months by Black Wednesday and the UKrsquos forced exit from the European Exchange Rate Mechanism.It never regained public trust.Then there was lsquoBack to Basicsrsquo, constant sex scandals, brown envelopes and cash-for-questions.Nicola Sturgeonrsquos government is certainly showing its age. Its failures are growing and it looks accident-prone. The Derek Mackay scandal has shaken it. Mr Salmondrsquos trial is round the corner. But it is definitely not on a par with the Major era.And Mr Carlaw, letrsquos remember, is no Tony Blair riding to the rescue. He comes reeking of Eau de Brexit and will be tainted by Boris Johnsonrsquos broken promises and screw ups.And yet the Major government does offer one lesson for Mr Carlaw.Once governments start to go off, public opinion can change rapidly.So Mr Carlaw will pursue a twin-track approach, sugar-coating his own party and throwing every bit of mud he can find at the Nationalists.He will try to make it sound like a moral failing to support the SNP, practically wicked to side with them.His goal will then be ensuring his folk go to the polls, while hoping the SNPrsquos folk get queasy and stay home.For all the fine talk of fairness and fresh ideas, the coming election will be a brutal fight over dferential turnout with the Union on the line.

title: crew-member-platform-off-shetland-thailand
story: The male crew member on the Tern Alpha  off Shetland had presented with "minor symptoms" after ing from a holiday in Thailand and is being treated by a medic.Tern Alpha is a fixed installation serving as a manned drilling and production installation in the East Shetland Basin of the northern North Sea.A spokesperson for Platform operator Taqa said: "A member of crew on board our Tern Alpha  has presented with minor symptoms after ing recently from holiday in Thailand."The inidual is being attended to by the medic on board the  and as a precaution he is remaining separated from the rest of the crew until the results of tests are known."Both the inidual and Taqa continue to take the appropriate actions and precautions in line with the UK Government guidelines."Taqa is working closely with the relevant authorities and has put in place travel restrictions to its offshore s by iniduals who have travelled recently to countries identied by the UK Government."https:www.heraldscotland news .coronavirus--scottish-patients-test-negative-leeds-mp-self-isolates-disease-fear The Scottish Government said  people have now been tested for the virus, officially named Covid- by the World Health Organisation.Separately, NHS Greater Glasgow and Clydesaid staff in protective suits from its public health team will begin visiting the homes of people who have complained of symptoms associated with the virus.They will undertake testing and offer advice.Dr Emilia Crighton, deputy director of public health at NHSGGC, said: "I would encourage anyone who needs advice or information on coronavirus to access the NHS Inform website."The risk of catching this illness in the UK is extremely low and only those ing from at-risk areas, or people in contact with someone diagnosed with the illness are at risk."Our staff carrying out the testing will be wearing protective clothing as a precautionary measure and we would appreciatethe public show their support for our staff."

title: new-cabinet-presses-ahead-points-based-migration-system
story: However, No  could not say when net migration would begin to fall. Details of the new system are expected to be published next week.Last night, the SNP said the UK Governmentrsquos plans would ldquodevastate Scotland and that its focus on cutting the numbers of low-skilled migrant workers was ldquomassively concerning.At the first meeting of senior ministers following the controversial reshuffle, which saw Sajid Javid resign as Chancellor, the Prime Minister told colleagues the Government was elected to improve the NHS, tackle crime and level up opportunity across the UK through investment in infrastructure, education and training and that the new One Nation Government had a ldquoresponsibility to level up and unite the country.One of the Governmentrsquos first measures will be to overhaul Britainrsquos immigration system and seek to begin to realise the Governmentrsquos long-term promise to cut levels of net migration.The PMrsquos deputy spokesman said the Cabinet, after discussion, had agreed to the implementation of a points-based system, which would be ldquosimpler and fairer than the current one.He explained: ldquoIt would not discriminate between countries and wouldthe democratic control of immigration to the British people. The PM stressed we must demonstrate that the UK is open and welcoming from talent from across the world but the new system would end reliance on importing cheap, low-skilled labour, bringing down immigration numbers overall.Under existing legislation, workers from the EU and European Economic Area countries can come to the UK to live or work without a visa. But Mr Johnson is keen to close the route for low-skilled migrants but short-term visas will be considered for occupations experiencing shortages.It has been calculated the new points-based system could cut the number of low-skilled EU migrants by , per year, which would represent a  per cent reduction in the numbers of EU citizens who come to the UK on a long-term basis.Asked about the possibility of a change in the salary cap, the spokesman declined to answer and said the details of the new system would be ldquoset out shortly.Questioned about how migration numbers would be cut, he said the new system would enable the Government to control the number of people coming into the UK it would, by its very nature, ldquoprovide the Government to control who comes in and out and would end the countryrsquos ldquoreliance on low-skilled workers.Askedthere was a target and how soon migrant numbers would fall, the spokesman simply repeated that details of the new system would be set out shortly.Pressed on whether there was discussion on any special dispensation for Scotland ndash the Scottish Government wants policy on immigration to be devolved ndash he said he would not go into the detail of Cabinetrsquos ldquowider discussion.But Stuart McDonald for the SNP described the Governmentrsquos approach as a ldquototal shambles.He noted how the Tory Government had had  months to produce proposals for a new migration system but people still knew ldquonext to nothing about what it will look like.Mr McDonald insisted: ldquoFree movement is about the only bit of the UK migration system that works well we should retain it, not scrap it.The MP for Cumbernauld, Kilsyth and Kirkintilloch East added: ldquoConfirmation Boris Johnson is still intent on cracking down on so-called low skilled migration is massively concerning. From hospitality to social care, agriculture to scientic research, many key industries across Scotland will no longer have access to vital workers we desperately need.

title: days-scotlands-interesting-12-festivals-2020
story: But thatrsquos not going to happen. Becausetherersquos stuff to be done out there in Scotland. Thrilling stuff. Edge of your seat stuff. Wow, thatrsquos totally crazy, I canrsquot believe itrsquos happening to me stuff.Oh sure, you could give it all a miss. Baton down the hatches and evade the clamour of culture. But deep down yoursquod always have that lurking suspicion that there were some dastardly folk out there having way more fun than you. In the end yoursquod be like a lemon trapped in a revolving door ndash bitter and twisted.So get ready for a feast of feisty festivals frolicking your way. Each event is guaranteed to sever you from your sofa.By Lorne JacksonGlasgow Film FestivalThe Oscars are over for another year, meaning a bunch of mediocrities have deposited their little gold statues in a bank vault and ed to their Hollywood swimming pools and Hollywood drug habits.The Academy Awards has always been about the survival of the blandest. Butyou want genuine quality and quirkiness, the Glasgow Film Festival is the place to be. There are cult flicks, sci fi flicks, scary flicks, feminist flicks and even locally made flicks. The festival isnrsquot just a movie screening bonanza. Watch out for quizzes, club nights, workshops and jazz sessions. . Guests include Saudi Arabiarsquos first female feature film director Haaa al-Mansour and leading documentary maker Jeanie Finlay. Feb- March glasgowfilm.org festivalEdinburgh International Improv FestivalGET ready for awkward silences galore as comedians struggle, strive and strain to come up with witticisms and one liners, then fall painfully short. Only joking.Therersquos bound to be loads of laugh aloud moments and brilrsquo bon mots as a jamboree of japesters take to the stage and attempt to find inspiration on the spot, and in the spot light. Andthey donrsquot  Just boo those bums off the stage and back into obscurity. Feb- March. edimrprovfestEdinburghrsquos Festival of IrelandMANY would argue that the best way to celebrate Ireland is by visiting Ireland. But isnrsquot that a little obvious  Much better to head over to the city of Edinburghwhere the rich culture of the Emerald Isle will descend on the city in all its raucous glory. This is a multi-arts, family friendly event involving storytelling, music, comedy and plenty of dancing. And will the whisky be served with that extra e in the namehellip or not  On this point alone there may be a clash of the Celtic nations.- March edinburghfestivalofireland.orgPuppet Animation FestivalThis is an opportunity to have loads of fun, with no strings attached. Actually thatrsquos not true. There will be plenty of strings attached, along with arms plunged into lelike dolls with googly eyes. This is one of the largest and longest running annual performing arts events for children, with events running in ious venues throughout Scotland. And will that block of finest mahogany, Pinocchio, turn up  Unlikely, as it seems all that Disney success has changed him. Rumour has it he wonrsquot get out of bed these days for under a million in spondoolickshellip March ndash  April puppetanimationfestival.orgDolphinFestNo, this isnrsquot a festival that only dolphins can attend. Humans are urged to get involved as well. The aim of DolphinFest is to encourage dolphin watching while ensuring the cute aquatic critters arenrsquot disturbed in their natural habitat. Therersquos a series of pop-up events across Aberdeen including interactive games, conservation talks, beach cleans and citizen science projects. Local schools will also get involved. In other words, somephin for everyone.- April, rspb.org.ukBonfestBon Scott was raised in Australia, where he also raised hell. But the AC DC front man and heavy metal legend, who died in his twenties from an excess of everything, was born in Kirriemuir, where this festival takes place. Usually a sleepy Angus town, you can bet it will be wide awake when metal fans from around the world descend to celebrate their hero with much musical din and decadent behaviour.No doubt there will also be a few Spinal Tap types strumming their air guitars far too loudly. Top tip: If this happens, itrsquos always best practice to unplug the air guitars from the air ampliers theyrsquore attached to. That usually quietens things down a bit.- May bonfestGlasgow Coffee FestivalA CONTROVERSIAL one, this. Everyone knows Glaswegians only drink whisky, Tennentrsquos Lager and Irn Bru.But a drink made from a bean  Surely the only purpose of any self-respecting bean is to be drenched in tomato sauce, then stuffed in a tin can. But perhaps wersquore not up to date with the ever so smooth and modern Glesga gargler. In which case itrsquos definitely time to swing down to The Briggait, where baristas, bar owners and roasters will be giving presentations and providing samples to sip. A perfect opportunity to start tippling that tart yet tasty pitch-black brew.- May glasgowcoffeefestivalKelburn Garden PartyThis music and arts festival takes place in a ravishing and wind-swept part of Scotlandrsquos West Coast thatrsquos not too far from Glasgow. Situated in the picturesque grounds surrounding Kelburn Castle, near Largs, you can either saturate yourself in the scenery or enjoy a erse live music line-up showcasing new artists from Scotland and around the world. Musical genres include techno, disco, funk, jazz, dub, jungle, house, afrobeat and folk music. In other words, a little bit of everything and anything. Therersquos also theatre, art installations and pop up parties to enjoy.- July kelburngardenpartyStrathaven Balloon FestivalShhhh! Donrsquot tell the organisers of this cloud-clambering event that the aeroplane was invented over a hundred years ago. It just might spoil their fun. Then again, aeroplanes are noisy beasts that have turned the adventure of long distance travel into a mundane activity involving not enough leg room and too many vacuous comments from the pilot. Whereas a hot air balloon jaunt is silky, silent and as splenderous as a Jules Verne ripping yarn. This extravaganza allows families to enjoy the stunning sight of hot air balloons as they launch and fly. Nowonly someone would bring back the zeppelinhellip- Aug strathavenballoonfestivalHuntly Hairst Food and Farming FestivalTherersquos plenty of locally sourced food to munch at this Aberdeenshire community event. Therersquos also lots to see and do, with everything connected to the culture of Huntlyrsquos farming folk. Local musicians will be on hand, providing a tuneful backdrop to a series of literary and food-based activities. For those of a combative nature, there are cooking and baking competitions. The perfect opportunity to crush your adversaries into the dust.The highlight of these feisty food wars will no doubt be the hotly contested World Stovies Championships. A competition as illustrious as the Olympics.  September huntlyhairstAye Write!What could be better than a festival with a pun in the title  Glasgowrsquos annual gathering of book-loving bods has something for everyone. For youngsters, comic novelist Philip Ardaghwill be celebrating the twentieth anniversary of his hilarious Eddie Dickens Trilogy. Therersquos plenty for adults too, including writing classes and talks from cookery book authors, crime scribes, published politicians and every other type of literary lion and lioness. Oh, yes, and former Speaker John Bercow will be there too. Order, order.- March . AyewriteGlasgow Festival of BurlesqueGet ready for some saucy shenanigans. No, that doesnrsquot mean enjoying the contents of a ketchup bottle. Burlesque is risqueacute routines, ravishing costumes and oodles of ooh-la-la. In other words, cabaret in all its curvy splendour. This sultry celebration will include a range of workshops and performances that are bound to be ripping fun. Or do we mean stripping fun  Perhaps not. After all, it does get a tad chilly for that sort of thing, come Novemberhellip- November glasgowfestivalofburlesque

title: rab-mcneil-bridge-sighs-bridge-ayes-boris-thinks-big
story: Here are a couple: HS and a bridge between Scotland and Northern Ireland. Propelling these in the prime ministerial bonce is a disturbing can-do attitude, a revival of the building brio of the Victorians who bludgeoned a transport infrastructure onto the country before anyone had a chance to say: ldquoHoy, wait a minute!But minutes matter, and commuters havenrsquot time to wait for them. Hence, HS, the high-speed rail link, will shave  minutes of the travelling time between London and Birmingham, thus rejuvenating the entire economy of Great Britain and making us once more the envy of the world.However, the measure is not supported by all Britons, some cavilling at the cost which, in the traditional manner of public projects, has risen from a microscopic pound. billion to a wee tiny poundbn.:Ian McConnell: Bizarre Boris bridge highlights Tory perception-reality gulfAs so often, it fell to top current affairs magazine Viz to devise, in its famous TopTips column, a solution that yoursquod have thought acceptable to all: ldquoLONDON businessmen. Save the government billions of pounds building a high speed rail link to Birmingham by arranging your meetings in Birmingham  minutes later.HS toucheacute! However, the Prime Minister of All Britain is having none of this and, emboldened by visions of his legacy as Boris the Bold, Boris the Good, Boris the Whizzo, his big bonce bobbed about once more and shook out his second great thought: a pound billion bridge between Scotland and Northern Ireland, bringing the two controversial provinces together in the same way that HS would cement a love between the north and south of England.This bridge, alas, has been greeted by the citizenry with a giant raspberry. Even Borisian loyalists in The Dailyhave derided it as bonkers. Here, Herald readers and other leading citizens denounced it as a vanity project, a cynical gimmick, a bread and circuses distraction from a noted classicist more Nero than Augustus.Critics highlighted the outrageous logistics, with a requirement for massive columns, and the need to negotiate a seabed where of tons of munitions sit aboot waiting for a chance to explode.They also point out that Isambard Kingdom Boris has previous with the failed London Garden Bridge project that turned pound million into fertiliser. Therersquos something peculiar about Boris and bridges. Is it Freudian  Is he forcing dferent parts of the country into conjugation  Is it all pants  Something to do with suspenders Who knows  At least he canrsquot take responsibility for the Queensferry Crossing, which dfers from all other bridges in the world because itrsquos an SNP bridge. And what is SNP, readers  Correct: SNP bad.To be fair, the Scandinavians arenrsquot used to cold weather. We in Scotland, on the other hand, have no excuse. To be even fairer, some critics fairly highlight not so much the closure as the failure to instal proper censors to detect dangerous ice formations, something that ought to have happened after similar incidents last year.Having sensed the danger, of course, the bridge would still have closed, but at least it would have been before the ice fell to the carriageway. To be fairer still, the Crossingrsquos defenders have been characterised as knee-jerk SNP loyalists. So, while itrsquos a Bridge of Sighs to some, itrsquos a Bridge of Ayes to others.Some of the former didnrsquot want a bridge at all, these being cannae Scots with a canrsquot do attitude that extends to running their own affairs. Funny old world. Those who can donrsquot. And those who do shouldnrsquot.++++OH, as it were, dear. Or, as the influential Daily Star newspaper put it: ldquoTherersquos been a f****** murder.Yep, the BBC continued on its kamikaze mission to lose friends and influence people with a production of Agatha Christiersquos The Pale Horse that took the decent and wholesome old murder story and littered it with f-bombs.Somebody was told to ldquof*** off. Someone was told to ldquouse a f****** ashtray, you bitch. There was a reference to ldquof****** donkeys. And someone warned: ldquoI will pop your eyes out of your f****** head.It has been claimed that these were not in the original text. Online, viewers castigated the production, with one saying gnomically: ldquoYou canrsquot say f*** in an Agatha Christie.One wonders what possessed the writer who adapted the original novel to do this. Itrsquos hardly cutting edge any more, or getting down with the kids.They must have known it would have aroused controversy, with their PR department thinking: ldquoAll publicity is good publicity. This news just in: no, it ainrsquot.The BBC used to be known for its productions of the classics. Now itrsquos a classic case of not knowing what the flipping heck itrsquos doing.++++ALERT readers may have noticed ructions in the Conservatives, a political party.Down in yonder Westminster, Sajid Javid resigned as Chancellor after the Tory Prime Minister, Bertie Johnson, demanded he sack all his aides.Apparently, Johnsonrsquos own first aide, Rasputin Machiavelli, didnrsquot think they were with the programme. Dirty though it seems, therersquos an evil logic in the move, with aides of Nos  and  merged into one group to forestall the PM v Chancellor animosities of old, such as that between Tony Blair and Broon.While Javid didnrsquot want to be seen as a ldquochino , Carlaw Jackson, or indeed vice-versa, was stepping into Ruth Davidonrsquos trousers as leader of the Scottish Conservatives.:Jackson Carlaw elected new leader of Scottish ConservativesThe former leading car salesman is thought to have gained a last-minute surge of support after slating a controversial bridge whose design hersquod helped to choose.Activists reasoned that anyone who could pull off that level of chicanery could lead their party to control all Scotland for No . However, some accuse Mr Jackson of lacking vision, and dislike the way he always seems to be laughing, ashe knew something that they didnrsquot, which they suspect might be their electoral chances.++++LITTLE beyond the odd BBC play shocks us any more. The world is a place of many marvels, populated by people whose passions, obsessions and heroic absurdities make peculiarity the norm.However, there are times when it all goes too far, when the weirdness makes us want to wail: ldquoEnough! Let us perish rather than suffer one more grotesquerie!That point was reached this week with a revelation in The Daily Mail that there are people on this planet who ndash and I donrsquot know how to tell you this, but will just come brutally to the point ndash collect the irritating little stickers that supermarkets put on fruit.Itrsquos true. They paste them into albums. When storms rattle the windows of an evening, they take them out and feel all safe and warm as they examine their little treasures with their intriguing mots and colourful images.And these collectors are not all sad anoraks. Among their number is Jarvis Cocker, former leader of The Pulps, a pop band!There are even niche sub-sections of this already most niche of hobbies. We are told of a Norwegian man who only collects banana stickers. How shocking. Still, itrsquos niche to be niche, isnrsquot it Read more: Video shops, video nasties and just plain nasty ndash come back Auntie, all is forgiven

title: opinion-matrix-reshuffle-shocks-power-balance
story: Rishi Sunak has taken over as chancellor of the exchequer with his first Budget looming next month.The Daily Its editorial says it is a matter of regret that he did not see it coming and adapt accordingly.It said: "Mr Javid is a bright political talent, but his brief record as chancellor did not reflect that potential. This newspaper has warned for weeks that the Government has everything going for it except for an economic policy. To make matters worse, word slipped out of the Treasury that policies were on the table for the next Budget that ought never to go near it, such as a raid on pensions or even mansion tax." It was then up to the then Chancellor to shoot these rumours down. He did not. Some reached the conclusion that Mr Javid had fallen prey to Treasury groupthink, that caught between Mr Johnsons plans and the established fiscal rules, Mr Javid had been persuaded by civil servants to consider socialist measures that even the last Labour government would never have touched."If true then this pattern of institutional capture is exactly why Mr Johnson and Dominic Cummings have chosen to go to war on Whitehall. If they want to get anything done, they have no choice."The TimesIn his column Philip Collins writes that Mr Johnson has rewarded the cabinets second-raters while removing anyone who might challenge his authority.He said: "Take back control. Get Javid Gone. In a petulant reshuffle empty of purpose, the school bullies showed the junior form whos boss. Three months ago Boris Johnson gave the CBI a categorical guarantee that Sajid Javid would remain as chancellor of the exchequer. Now he has gone for no less a reason than that the prime ministers consigliere Dominic Cummings wanted to consolidate his power base. The consequence is a cabinet full of cartoon characters, which is just as Mr Cummings wants it."It is always telling when a prime minister goes out of his way to appoint the C-team. One of the temperamental traits that will make Mr Johnson a weak premier is that, like many people prone to displays of bravura, he is tormented by the fear that he is not up to the job."The ScotsmanThe papers editorial suggests there are worrying signs for One-Nation Tories.It said: "There are rumours that tensions between Cummings and Sajid Javid led to the Chancellors shock resignation, just four weeks before the UK Budget. Sources claimed Javid had refused to fire his own special advisers and replace them with ones sent from Number ."The papers editorial goes on to mention other high profile departures including Andrea Leadsom, Geoffrey Cox and Julian Smith.It added: "The concern about such changes is that they suggest Johnson is no longer the One Nation Tory that he has been in the past and that he is demanding loyalty to an excessive degree - a sign of weakness, not strength. Members of the Cabinet should be signed up to broad policy objectives, but they should not fear losing their jobsthey have specic disagreements with the boss."And, to be clear, that boss is Johnson, not Cummings, and the buck stops with him."Polly Toynbee writes in her column that "this revenge reshuffle shows absolute power resides in No ."She said: "The message of this reshuffle is a nasty and dangerous one: absolute power resides in just one place, No .The Treasury, which strove to protect the nations finances against the worst damages of Brexit, is a diminished force - for now. Attempts to thwart Johnsons reckless plans - whether branded super-bridges or Brexit vanity projects - will be overridden. If Whitehall joked that Javid was "chino" - chancellor in name only- his successor can expect even less respect."Although the power of Cummings now seems unprecedented, seasoned observers are waiting for him to overstep the mark. No one is indispensable, a truism of prime ministerial power. The prime minister will be quick to jettison anyone imperilling his popularity, including his svengali."

title: letters-tories-can-no-longer-claim-safe-custodians-treasury
story: Butthese tax plans are dropped will it not cause a huge hole in the projected tax incomes, incomes that are desperately needed to see us through the three years or so before any potential benefits from trade deals begin to trickle through  The ticking debt time bomb that is Brexit in  is edging ever closer, the current cost-effective movement of our goods, services and people will stop and the pound billion opportunity cost of Brexit will have to be accounted for.Money will be tight, and there is a triple lock on increases in income tax, National Insurance Contribution and VAT, so how will Boris Johnson meet his promised election commitments, including to the National Health Service and the police The Tories proved their fiscal incompetence with their failed promises to reduce the debt through austerity, measures which continue to cause incredible hardships to the poorest, along with devastation of our public services. Unless Mr Johnson defers his election promises to some distant horizon, a magic money tree will have to be conjured. It is time the Tory facade of being safe custodians at the Treasury was exposed, their incompetence at fiscal management fully revealed to the electorate.Paul Shaw, Dunblane.ON hearing that Sajid Javid had resigned, Kate Forbes on Twitter offered her assistance to prepare a Budget. The new Chancellor of the Exchequer, Rishi Sunak, read economics at Oxford, worked for Goldman Sachs and then founded an investment firm. Kate Forbes read history at Cambridge and then gained an MSC in Diaspora and Migration History. I know which one I would want to be in charge of a budget and it is not Ms Forbes, who seems to have let the success of reading out Derek Mackayrsquos budget out in Holyrood go to her head.Jane Lax, Aberlour.ACCORDING to the Office of National Statistics, the UK National Debt at the end of  stood at pound, billion or . per cent of GDP.Average household debt reached a peak of pound, .However, the good news is that the recently elected Government has the answer. During the long cold years of austerity, the government has been combating the growing problem of dealing with CO emissions by planting forests of money trees which are now yielding such magnicent crops that we can now afford to repay billions to the EU, fund the HS rail link which seemed to casual observers to be a problem and contemplate building a bridge or tunnel to Ireland. Has anyone mentioned the possible repairs to the Westminster Parliament buildings  And even dont speak about Trident.No doubt local councils up and down the land will be queuing up for cuttings from those bountul trees, as despite reducing much needed services and delving into well scraped barrels, they are running out of options to meet the needs of their communities.When questioned about how the Government would be able to meet increasing demands within the NHS and where, the PM replied that there was "fiscal headroom". We have to assume that this is political speak for "borrowing".Keep tending those trees as , they fail, we might see the state pension age rising to .Walter Mitty is alive and well and lives in London.Malcolm Allan, Bishopbriggs.WHO is running the country  Well, it is certainly not the Prime Minister, Boris Johnson, but could it be someone from across the pond as yesterdayrsquos evidence of the Cabinet re-shuffle revealed  Disagree with or question the PM, "youre fired" will certainly follow. Could our once-great democracy be under threat, with the great unelected deciding  It certainly looks like that.Never mind a bridge too far, is this a step too far Catriona C Clark, Falkirk.AS former ministers reshuffle off the scene there is a strong whf of deja vu emanating from Downing Street, where we have a blond Prime Minister who seems hell bent on ridding the Cabinet of all who are not perceived as being acquiescent team players all thats missing is the handbag.Ruth Marr, Stirling."DOM subs sub Domsrsquo might have been how Boris Johnson would have headlined the Machiavellian plot to install a more subservient Chancer of the Exchequer.It sounds enough like Latin to fool the common herd.Duncan Graham, Stirling.READING the reports in The Herald today about all the skulduggery going on in Westminster, should the old song be rewritten, such a parcel o rogues in Westminster John Aitken, Falkirk.IT would appear that Boris Johnsonrsquos Brexit plan is starting to show signs of firm progress already, just a couple of weeks since the UK formally left the EU. The European Parliament has given solid support to Spainrsquos right to veto any Brexit agreement regarding Gibraltar and to support the decolonisation of Gibraltar.SoMr Johnsonrsquos plan was intended to break up what remains of the British Empire thenseems to have made a good start.Developments in Ireland and in Scotland are also moving towards a united Ireland and an independent Scotland so with any luck Mr Johnson will achieve a situation that by the time he has to face the electorate again it will English voters only, where he stands a much better chance of re-election. Of course, England will then be a much smaller country and GDP per head will be signicantly reduced, buthis luck holds Mr Johnson and his hedge fund backers will still be doing OK for themselves.Andy Anderson, Saltcoats.Read more: Javid paid the price on a day of brutal Cummings and goings

title: 1m-research-climate-change-affecting-scotlands-peatlands
story: Dr Roxane Andersen, from the Environmental Research Institute at North Highland College UHI, will use the pound, funding to explore how climate change could affect blanket bogs and to assess the effectiveness of restoration efforts.The research leadership award, provided by the Leverhulme Trust, will enable Dr Andersen to develop a team of nine researchers, who will conduct the investigations over a five-year period.They will use cutting-edge technologies and techniques, including satellite remote sensing, to investigate how we can protect and restore blanket bog areas. Peatlands are renowned for their ability to soak up carbon dioxide from the atmosphere, to promote bioersity and to provide high quality water.The Thurso-based scientists will benefit from access to the Flow Country, the largest blanket bog in Europe and a region that is under consideration for World Heritage Site status ndash joining the ranks of Australiarsquos Great Barrier Reef, the Grand Canyon in America and the Taj Mahal in India.The project will also support new initiatives across the universityrsquos research centres and foster national and international collaborations, including work with Canadian peatland research groups.Dr Andersen said: ldquoPeatlands are the Earthrsquos most efficient terrestrial carbon store. They regulate water and climate and support unique bioersity.ldquoHowever, their degradation affects the delivery of these key s. In the UK, the cool, wet climate supports a globally rare peatland type: blanket bogs.ldquoMost UK blanket bogs have been degraded by human activities and, left alone, they make a signicant contribution to our greenhouse gas emissions from the land use sector. However, unprecedented efforts to restore our blanket bogs are under way, for example through the Peatland Action programme in Scotland.ldquoAstonishingly, we do not know the extent to which these interventions work or how blanket bogs, restored or otherwise, will cope with the added threat of climate change.ldquoI am thrilled to have been chosen by the Leverhulme Trust for this Research Leadership Award. I look forward to working with my team to pioneer approaches from molecular to landscape scales to fill some of these gaps in our knowledge and to inform UK and global peatland management strategies.The project will focus on three key areas of research. The team will explore how environmental conditions can affect Sphagnum mosses, one of the building blocks of peat in blanket bog.They will continue to develop a method that uses satellite data to measure how the seasonal patterns of swelling and shrinking of bog surface, known as ldquobog breathing, change in response to climate extremes and restoration activities. They will also work to refine models that predict how blanket bogs may respond to dferent management approaches in future climate change scenarios.Emma Goodyer, manager of the International Union For The Conservation Of Nature Uk Peatland Programme, said: ldquoThe area covered by near natural peatland worldwidestores more carbon than all other vegetation types in the world combined. However, drained and damaged peatlands contribute about  per cent of greenhouse gas emissions from the land use sector annually, despite covering only .% of the global land surface.ldquoScotland has become a global leader in peatland management. The research hub in the Flow Country has been instrumental in delivering programmes of research that tackle some of the most pressing issues for peatland restoration and policy. This signicant funding boost will offer the opportunity to understand the resilience of peatland ecosystems in the face of the climate crisis whilst also reversing bioersity losses.The Flow Country of Caithness and Sutherland has bogs in the tundra-like landscape that have been growing since the end of the last Ice Age more than , years ago. The arearsquos peat is up to ft deep and its soil stores about  million tons of carbon.Wildle in the area include otters, deer and common scoter ducks.In the UK, common scoters breed at only a few locations, including the Flow Country and the lochs and and glens near Inverness.Six of the UKrsquos  World Heritage sites are in Scotland.

title: bearsden-climber-battling-tough-weather---climbed-10-peaks-one-day
story: Halfway through epic  Munro trekKevin Woods yesterday the red, on the ridges above Glen AffricKevin Woods, , from Bearsden, East Dunbartonshire, set off on his ambitious expedition on December , the day of the winter solstice. The following day he climbed the four Munros around Ben Cruachan, covering over  miles and , metres of ascent.He spent Christmas Day around the Crianlarich hills, and on Hogmanay ascended the mountains of Glen Coe.Now he has reached the halfway point of his epic journey,  days after starting up Ben More on Mull.On February , Mr Woods, who over the course of  summited  peaks, stepped on to the icy summit of Stob Choire Claurigh, Lochaber, in the pre-dawn gloom at .am. It was hisst peak, halfway to his target of completing the ascent of the  Scottish mountains over ,ft.Despite the early hour, it was already his second mountain of the day ndash he had bagged Stob Ban, a mile back down the ridge, after a .am start by head-torch from Lairig Leacach bothy. He then continued over the Grey Corries range and after nine hours climbing he crossed the plateau of Ben Nevis, in thickly falling snow.Mr Woods is being supported by friends and relatives who are delivering food and other supplies, but normally he climbs alone because he is too fast for most to keep upHe said: ldquoThe season so far has been one storm into another, wersquove just had westerlies off the ocean for weeks, since I started.Late January saw some of the worst ground conditions so far, with deep soft snow piled in the wilds of Atholl, north of Pitlochry.In Glen Diridh he was ldquowading through it, slipping, falling over, on your knees, up again. It was one of the few points where I felt, this is very, very tough.The next day he was on Beinn arsquoGhlo when the Cairngorm summit weather station was recordingmph gusts.He said: ldquoIt was just like flicking on a switch. Suddenly I was clenching my walking poles, digging them into the ground, and staggering forward between the blasts, the wind roaring in my ears.Three days later, the Ben Nevis range provided his biggest haul of peaks ndash  ndash in a single day since setting out, and one of his few rest days followed ndash only his third in the  days of his expedition to date.On February  he crossed the Great Glen into the north-west Highlands, summiting Meall na Teanga and Sron arsquoChoire Ghairbh above Loch Lochy with blue skies above.But on Tuesday, his fears were confirmed when he had to abandon the climb. He said: ldquoThe hills were wild, a hard wind with big snow showers moving through. Ten minutes out of Achnasheen and rumbles of thunder made a decision for me. We donrsquot play God. Some days arenrsquot to be.

title: emily-thornberry-eliminated-labour-leadership-race-succeed-jeremy-corbyn
story: At the midnight Friday deadline, the shadow foreign secretary had  nominations from local constituency parties ndash two short of the  she required to go forward.She did not get any nominations from Labour Party affiliates ndash the other route onto the ballot paper.The three other candidates still in the contest ndash Sir Keir Starmer, Rebecca Long-Bailey and Lisa Nandy ndash had already obtained the nominations they needed.They now go through to the online and postal ballot of party members and registered supporters which opens on February .:Labourrsquos Long-Bailey promises to take on the mediarsquos lsquovested interestsrsquoFollowing the confirmation of the result, Ms Thornberry said it was a ldquoshame she had not gone through, but praised her ldquobrilliant campaign team.ldquoWe had a standing start after the election, and operated on a shoe string, but we gave it everything, she said in a statement.She paid tribute to the party supporters determined to fight back after Decemberrsquos general election defeat at the hands of the Tories.Its a shame to miss out on the rest of the race, but good luck to the three superb remaining candidates. Huge thanks to members from all corners of the UK who supported me, and to my brilliant campaign team. It wasnt to be, but we gave it everything. My full statement is here. pic hWhfWcTTgmdash Emily ThornberryFebruary , ldquoIt was on their behalf that I stood for the leadership, because Irsquove always believed we are at out best when ndash from the dispatch box to the doorstep ndash we are one, united fighting force, taking on the Tories and standing up for the communities we represent.Ms Thornberry had struggled for support throughout the contest.:Kevin McKenna: SNPrsquos female talent deserves better than lsquotrans warriorrsquo abuseShe only scraped through the first round of nominations by Labour MPs and MEPs with  votes ndash one more than the  required ndash after Clive Lewis dropped out.In part of a last-ditch effort to remain in the contest, she announced she would bring in public sector pension reformsshe took Labour into Downing Street.The opposition frontbencher told Politics Home she planned to give workers access to their pension pots before they retire in a move designed to ease Government debt and boost the economy.She admitted she had suffered from a ldquosqueeze by the ldquomonolithic campaigns of Sir Keir and Ms Long-Bailey.The final result of the election will be announced at a special conference in London on April .

title: bristol-banksy-art-vandalised-just-24-hours
story: A picture shared on social media showed ldquoBCC W*****S scrawled across the artwork, which shows a young girl firing a slingshot.One local resident who spotted the vandalism said: ldquoItrsquos a real shame, but it was always going to happen unfortunately.Residents in the Barton Hill area of the city awoke on Thursday to find the striking piece on the side of a building.The artwork, in Marsh Lane, features a stencilled image of a girl firing a slingshot of red flowers and leaves.Banksy confirmed the piece by posting two images of it on his official Instagram account and website in the early hours of Valentinersquos Day.The artwork appeared on a rented home owned by Edwin Simons, who celebrated his th birthday on Thursday.His daughter, Kelly Woodruff, , found out about it after being tagged in a Facebook post.

title: labour-candidates-quizzed-indyref2-leadership-hustings-held-glasgow
story: The shadow business secretary spoke out as the Labour leadership hustings came to Glasgow, where she was the only one of the three remaining candidates to explicitly state she could support a fresh ballot on independence.Ms Long-Bailey and her fellow Leadership hopefuls, shadow Brexit secretary Sir Keir Starmer and Lisa Nandy, all stressed the importance of Labour winning back support in Scotland as a route back to power across the UK.:Labourrsquos Long-Bailey promises to take on the mediarsquos lsquovested interestsrsquoMs Nandy, the shadow climate change secretary, said: ldquoThere is no route to government that doesnrsquot run through Scotland, but the challenge of this is absolutely enormous.She added: ldquoWe haveto start winning in every region and nation of the UK, because we have to show we area national party of government.Similarly Sir Keir said: ldquoWe canrsquot win without Scotland so we have to rebuild in Scotland.Ms Long-Bailey also echoed that, telling activists at the event: ldquoWe wonrsquot win a general election without Scotland.With the hustings taking place in Scotland, issues over independence and the constitution dominated the early questions to the three candidates.Asked directlythe Scottish Parliament should have the power to stage a legally binding vote on independence Ms Long-Bailey said: ldquoIrsquom proud to be from the United Kingdom but as a democrat I have to say thatthe Scottish Parliament makes the request for a referendum I donrsquot believe that as a democratic party we could refuse that.Her comments came after MSPs at Holyrood voted by  to  last month in favour of a second independence referendum taking place.If there is a second vote on Scottish independence she said Labour could make a ldquopositive campaign for the union.But she was clear: ldquoWe canrsquot fall into the trap we did last time where we joined forces with the Conservative Party on Better Together.However Sir Keir said that by backing a second independence vote, Labour could be falling into a ldquotrap set by the SNP.:Iain Macwhirter: In post-Brexit Britain, Nicola Sturgeon cant keep telling her troops that Indyref is round the corner. It isntHe said the issue of Holyrood having the power to stage a fresh ballot on the issue was ldquoan interesting question but he added: ldquoWe shouldnrsquot get sucked straight into that.ldquoThe SNP are constantly using the constitutional issue to mask the real issues, andwe get into that we are falling into their trap.ldquoLetrsquos have a wide discussion about where we go next, but letrsquos be bold about it.He argued that Labour should support ldquoradical federalism as the way forward for the UK.Meanwhile Ms Nandy said she believed in a ldquomuch more radical power settlement than federalism with power pushed out to local authorities.She told Labour Party members: ldquoI believe in the United Kingdom and I think we have to be absolutely clearabout that and we have to stand up for Scotland remaining in the United Kingdom.ldquoWe can hand power to people and give people agency and control over their own lives again by handing more powers to our councils.
